Blurb
Overview
This module concludes a series of practical human anatomy modules in the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology. Students will select a region of the body according to their interests, and work to apply the knowledge gained over the course of their studies to produce a detailed anatomical prosection.

Over the course of a full semester, students develop in-depth knowledge of anatomy through a regional approach during a focused dissection project, acquiring new knowledge, appreciation for anatomical variation and complexity, and building existing dissection skills. Deeper knowledge is gained through an investigation into a research topic on the region they have chosen, by critically evaluating and presenting relevant scientific literature to peers.

Students on this module will gain an appreciation of anatomical or clinical problems facing the modern world, and how their skills and knowledge can be applied towards solving these problems in various workplace settings.

The module will be assessed through a mixture of written, oral and practical tasks, including the quality of their final prosection. The students are assessed on their abilities to communicate science effectively in the form of a flash talk and poster. Assessments build on existing skills and develop further skills around communication to broad audiences, analysing multi-faceted problems and critical thinking.
Educational Aims
This module aims to develop in learners:

• An enhanced knowledge of a particular topographical region through cadaveric dissection.
• The confidence to work independently on a dissection, to effectively and efficiently achieve their own individual dissection aims.
• A professional set of practical anatomical skills acquired through systematic cadaveric examination and appraisal.
• An understanding of employment opportunities and applications of human anatomy in fields ranging from clinical medicine, education, biomechanics and human movement, and medical imaging, through examination of the literature and a topic of their choice.
• An ability to confidently communicate anatomical concepts and findings in a variety of formats to a broad audience.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is a core component in Year 3 of the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology. It is a practical module that includes cadaveric dissection in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC).

Over the course of a full semester, students conduct a thorough and systematic exploration of the gross and functional anatomy of a region of their choice, through cadaveric dissection and investigation into a unique research topic.

Students build upon the foundational knowledge and skills developed in earlier modules at an advanced level, gaining an appreciation of anatomical or clinical problems facing the modern world, and how their skills and knowledge can be applied towards solving these problems in various workplace settings.

The module will be assessed through a mixture of written, oral and practical tasks.
Outline Syllabus
This module concludes a series of practical human anatomy modules in the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology.

The module begins with selecting a region of the body according to the students’ interests, and proceeds with students working to produce a detailed anatomical prosection of that region. Students will be guided in this process by skilled academics who will provide guidance throughout the module.

Deeper knowledge is gained through an investigation into a research topic on the region they have chosen, by critically evaluating and communicating relevant scientific literature and concepts. Students will have a choice of contemporary issues in anatomy to focus on, which may include but are not limited to; functional anatomy and biomechanics, human movement, frailty and ageing, ailments, injuries and conditions that affect human health.

The module will conclude with a conference style event where students are assessed on their abilities to communicate science effectively in the form of a flash talk and poster.
Teaching and Learning Methods
HARC Practicals (36 hours): Takes place in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC). Interactive exploration of key anatomical structures through a regional approach. Includes individual cadaveric examination and dissection. Cadaveric dissection is an extremely active process. It requires real-time synthesis and comprehension of the structures encountered to successfully progress. During these guided practicals, students will have 1-2-1 feedback from the lead academic and anatomy demonstrators, who will ask questions and prompt discussion about the anatomy the students encounter and the research topic they choose.

Authentic assessment: An oral examination (viva) is a highly authentic assessment of specialist knowledge – in this case, a demonstration of their cadaveric prosection to summarise their anatomical knowledge. The communication assessment requires students to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge in a digestible manner in two different formats: a poster and a 3-minute flash talk. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Independent learning (114 hours): The student directed learning element of the module will involve: planning for their dissection procedure; directed anatomical reading and accessing online resources such as anatomical models; searching the literature and critically appraising articles. Drop-in sessions will also be available for independent dissection time. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Attendance Recorded: yes

The literature review and flash talk assessments help studens to develop an understanding of employment and the vast range of medical/clinical, laboratory, evolutionary, biomechanics and research topics that involve anatomy. Further to this, the students decide what area they want to focus on, so this is flexible if students are interested in clinical medicine, dentistry, physiotherapy, research or education.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed through a mixture of written, oral and practical tasks, including formative assessments for feedback and preparation for summative assessment. The assessments are highly authentic and develop important graduate attributes.

• Prosection quality and written reflection (500 words) on procedure and outcomes (Weighting 35% - TBC). This assesses the students planning, preparation and skills in dissection. To produce a detailed, clean and unique anatomical prosection, student will need to plan and revise the anatomy, problem solve and critically think about anatomical variation, and reflect on the procedure and outcomes. The accompanying written reflection will include their individual reflection on the dissection procedure/process, identification of anatomical variations, whether they achieved their original aims, and their personal self-reflection on progress, planning, and time management, to achieve the final prosection. The reflection should be personal and flexible.

• A science communication piece on a literature-based research topic related to the students prosection (Weighting 35% - TBC). This task requires students to choose an aspect of anatomy related to their prosection and explain its importance in an applied context of their choosing from independent research. They must produce two outputs, to communicate the same information in different formats: a poster and a 3-minute flash talk.

• Oral viva (Weighting 30% - TBC). A traditional face-to-face oral examination where students can demonstrate their anatomical knowledge of the prosection through a practical demonstration, followed by question and answers.

These assessment take various forms to ensure an inclusive mix of assignments and opportunities for students to learn. Formative opportunities to communicate their understanding of anatomy and their research topic will take place throughout the semester during 1-2-1 feedback with the lead academic and anatomy demonstrators during the guided practicals.

These assessments are authentic assessments (written, oral and practical tasks) that fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning, including how to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge in different formats.

Inclusion (EDI) has been considered in the design of these assessments for different learning styles and abilities by having a range of formats that favour different skills (a mixture of written, oral and practical tasks). Adjustments including late submissions and resits are in line with SOLS policies.

Reassessment for science communication piece and viva assessments the will use the same format but the topic my differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Due to the nature of the Prosection Assessment (continuous practical work on a dissection over 12 weeks), this assessment is not available as a resit. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submissions of written work.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Health and Safety
Practical sessions take place in Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC), where all activity must comply with Human Tissue Authority (HTA) regulations. Learners must not be aged under 18.

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Demonstrate the ability to select an appropriate dissection in line with their interests.
 LO2 Produce a clean multi-layered prosection with anatomical structures in situ, that clearly displays structures of their own choice (e.g., joint contents, surrounding blood vessels, peripheral nerves).
 LO3 Access and critically evaluate scientific literature in the area of anatomical sciences.
 LO4 Synthesise information on current technologies and relevant fields within anatomical sciences.
 LO5 Interpret the significance of anatomical variation in the contexts of health and disease.
Skills
 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Self-directed independent learning and reflection.
 S2 Perform systematic examination of human cadaveric material in a safe and professional manner.
 S3 Critical Thinking.
 S4 Scientific Communication - Communicate scientific knowledge confidently to a specified audience using appropriate terminology.
 S5 Show awareness of ethical and legal constraints of working with cadaveric material.

Applied Anatomy and Dissection 2026-27

Org Unit:Life Sciences NEW
Level:Level 6
Credits:15
Module Code:BIOS304
Delivery:Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 
In Programme:Anatomy & Human Biology BSc (Hons) 2024-25

Approval Status

Life Sciences Curriculum Board
  Approving
Life and Human Sciences Scrutiny Panel
  Pending
Details
Module Title
Applied Anatomy and Dissection
Short Title
Applied Anatomy and Dissection
Module Code
BIOS304
Academic Year
2026-27
Org Unit
Life Sciences NEW
Delivery Locations
Liverpool campus
Delivery Periods
Semester 2
Credits
15
Level
Level 6
Module Coordinator
Alana Sharp
Other Staff
Assigned To
Life Sciences Curriculum Board
Quality Team
Status
 
Development Approval
Date of Approval
11 Jan 2024, 15:11
External Examiner(s)
Eilidh Ferguson
Continuing Professional Development
No
Maximum Places
40
Replaces
Advanced Human Topographical Anatomy 2026-27
HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
This module concludes a series of practical human anatomy modules in the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology. Students will select a region of the body according to their interests, and work to apply the knowledge gained over the course of their studies to produce a detailed anatomical prosection.

Over the course of a full semester, students develop in-depth knowledge of anatomy through a regional approach during a focused dissection project, acquiring new knowledge, appreciation for anatomical variation and complexity, and building existing dissection skills. Deeper knowledge is gained through an investigation into a research topic on the region they have chosen, by critically evaluating and presenting relevant scientific literature to peers.

Students on this module will gain an appreciation of anatomical or clinical problems facing the modern world, and how their skills and knowledge can be applied towards solving these problems in various workplace settings.

The module will be assessed through a mixture of written, oral and practical tasks, including the quality of their final prosection. The students are assessed on their abilities to communicate science effectively in the form of a flash talk and poster. Assessments build on existing skills and develop further skills around communication to broad audiences, analysing multi-faceted problems and critical thinking.
Educational Aims
This module aims to develop in learners:

• An enhanced knowledge of a particular topographical region through cadaveric dissection.
• The confidence to work independently on a dissection, to effectively and efficiently achieve their own individual dissection aims.
• A professional set of practical anatomical skills acquired through systematic cadaveric examination and appraisal.
• An understanding of employment opportunities and applications of human anatomy in fields ranging from clinical medicine, education, biomechanics and human movement, and medical imaging, through examination of the literature and a topic of their choice.
• An ability to confidently communicate anatomical concepts and findings in a variety of formats to a broad audience.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is a core component in Year 3 of the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology. It is a practical module that includes cadaveric dissection in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC).

Over the course of a full semester, students conduct a thorough and systematic exploration of the gross and functional anatomy of a region of their choice, through cadaveric dissection and investigation into a unique research topic.

Students build upon the foundational knowledge and skills developed in earlier modules at an advanced level, gaining an appreciation of anatomical or clinical problems facing the modern world, and how their skills and knowledge can be applied towards solving these problems in various workplace settings.

The module will be assessed through a mixture of written, oral and practical tasks.
Outline Syllabus
This module concludes a series of practical human anatomy modules in the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology.

The module begins with selecting a region of the body according to the students’ interests, and proceeds with students working to produce a detailed anatomical prosection of that region. Students will be guided in this process by skilled academics who will provide guidance throughout the module.

Deeper knowledge is gained through an investigation into a research topic on the region they have chosen, by critically evaluating and communicating relevant scientific literature and concepts. Students will have a choice of contemporary issues in anatomy to focus on, which may include but are not limited to; functional anatomy and biomechanics, human movement, frailty and ageing, ailments, injuries and conditions that affect human health.

The module will conclude with a conference style event where students are assessed on their abilities to communicate science effectively in the form of a flash talk and poster.
Teaching and Learning Methods
HARC Practicals (36 hours): Takes place in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC). Interactive exploration of key anatomical structures through a regional approach. Includes individual cadaveric examination and dissection. Cadaveric dissection is an extremely active process. It requires real-time synthesis and comprehension of the structures encountered to successfully progress. During these guided practicals, students will have 1-2-1 feedback from the lead academic and anatomy demonstrators, who will ask questions and prompt discussion about the anatomy the students encounter and the research topic they choose.

Authentic assessment: An oral examination (viva) is a highly authentic assessment of specialist knowledge – in this case, a demonstration of their cadaveric prosection to summarise their anatomical knowledge. The communication assessment requires students to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge in a digestible manner in two different formats: a poster and a 3-minute flash talk. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Independent learning (114 hours): The student directed learning element of the module will involve: planning for their dissection procedure; directed anatomical reading and accessing online resources such as anatomical models; searching the literature and critically appraising articles. Drop-in sessions will also be available for independent dissection time. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Attendance Recorded: yes

The literature review and flash talk assessments help studens to develop an understanding of employment and the vast range of medical/clinical, laboratory, evolutionary, biomechanics and research topics that involve anatomy. Further to this, the students decide what area they want to focus on, so this is flexible if students are interested in clinical medicine, dentistry, physiotherapy, research or education.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed through a mixture of written, oral and practical tasks, including formative assessments for feedback and preparation for summative assessment. The assessments are highly authentic and develop important graduate attributes.

• Prosection quality and written reflection (500 words) on procedure and outcomes (Weighting 35% - TBC). This assesses the students planning, preparation and skills in dissection. To produce a detailed, clean and unique anatomical prosection, student will need to plan and revise the anatomy, problem solve and critically think about anatomical variation, and reflect on the procedure and outcomes. The accompanying written reflection will include their individual reflection on the dissection procedure/process, identification of anatomical variations, whether they achieved their original aims, and their personal self-reflection on progress, planning, and time management, to achieve the final prosection. The reflection should be personal and flexible.

• A science communication piece on a literature-based research topic related to the students prosection (Weighting 35% - TBC). This task requires students to choose an aspect of anatomy related to their prosection and explain its importance in an applied context of their choosing from independent research. They must produce two outputs, to communicate the same information in different formats: a poster and a 3-minute flash talk.

• Oral viva (Weighting 30% - TBC). A traditional face-to-face oral examination where students can demonstrate their anatomical knowledge of the prosection through a practical demonstration, followed by question and answers.

These assessment take various forms to ensure an inclusive mix of assignments and opportunities for students to learn. Formative opportunities to communicate their understanding of anatomy and their research topic will take place throughout the semester during 1-2-1 feedback with the lead academic and anatomy demonstrators during the guided practicals.

These assessments are authentic assessments (written, oral and practical tasks) that fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning, including how to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge in different formats.

Inclusion (EDI) has been considered in the design of these assessments for different learning styles and abilities by having a range of formats that favour different skills (a mixture of written, oral and practical tasks). Adjustments including late submissions and resits are in line with SOLS policies.

Reassessment for science communication piece and viva assessments the will use the same format but the topic my differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Due to the nature of the Prosection Assessment (continuous practical work on a dissection over 12 weeks), this assessment is not available as a resit. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submissions of written work.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Health and Safety
Practical sessions take place in Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC), where all activity must comply with Human Tissue Authority (HTA) regulations. Learners must not be aged under 18.

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Demonstrate the ability to select an appropriate dissection in line with their interests.
 LO2 Produce a clean multi-layered prosection with anatomical structures in situ, that clearly displays structures of their own choice (e.g., joint contents, surrounding blood vessels, peripheral nerves).
 LO3 Access and critically evaluate scientific literature in the area of anatomical sciences.
 LO4 Synthesise information on current technologies and relevant fields within anatomical sciences.
 LO5 Interpret the significance of anatomical variation in the contexts of health and disease.
Skills
 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Self-directed independent learning and reflection.
 S2 Perform systematic examination of human cadaveric material in a safe and professional manner.
 S3 Critical Thinking.
 S4 Scientific Communication - Communicate scientific knowledge confidently to a specified audience using appropriate terminology.
 S5 Show awareness of ethical and legal constraints of working with cadaveric material.

The reflection should be personal and flexible.

• A science communication piece on a literature-based research topic related to the students prosection (Weighting 35% - TBC). This task requires students to choose an aspect of anatomy related to their prosection and explain its importance in an applied context of their choosing from independent research. They must produce two outputs, to communicate the same information in different formats: a poster and a 3-minute flash talk.

• Oral viva (Weighting 30% - TBC). A traditional face-to-face oral examination where students can demonstrate their anatomical knowledge of the prosection through a practical demonstration, followed by question and answers.

These assessment take various forms to ensure an inclusive mix of assignments and opportunities for students to learn. Formative opportunities to communicate their understanding of anatomy and their research topic will take place throughout the semester during 1-2-1 feedback with the lead academic and anatomy demonstrators during the guided practicals.

These assessments are authentic assessments (written, oral and practical tasks) that fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning, including how to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge in different formats.

Inclusion (EDI) has been considered in the design of these assessments for different learning styles and abilities by having a range of formats that favour different skills (a mixture of written, oral and practical tasks). Adjustments including late submissions and resits are in line with SOLS policies.

Reassessment for science communication piece and viva assessments the will use the same format but the topic my differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Due to the nature of the Prosection Assessment (continuous practical work on a dissection over 12 weeks), this assessment is not available as a resit. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submissions of written work.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Health and Safety
Practical sessions take place in Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC), where all activity must comply with Human Tissue Authority (HTA) regulations. Learners must not be aged under 18.

In Programme:Anatomy & Human Biology BSc (Hons) 2024-25

Blurb
Overview
This module concludes a series of practical human anatomy modules in the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology. Students will select a region of the body according to their interests, and work to apply the knowledge gained over the course of their studies to produce a detailed anatomical prosection.

Over the course of a full semester, students develop in-depth knowledge of anatomy through a regional approach during a focused dissection project, acquiring new knowledge, appreciation for anatomical variation and complexity, and building existing dissection skills. Deeper knowledge is gained through an investigation into a research topic on the region they have chosen, by critically evaluating and presenting relevant scientific literature to peers.

Students on this module will gain an appreciation of anatomical or clinical problems facing the modern world, and how their skills and knowledge can be applied towards solving these problems in various workplace settings.

The module will be assessed through a mixture of written, oral and practical tasks, including the quality of their final prosection. The students are assessed on their abilities to communicate science effectively in the form of a flash talk and poster. Assessments build on existing skills and develop further skills around communication to broad audiences, analysing multi-faceted problems and critical thinking.
Educational Aims
This module aims to develop in learners:

• An enhanced knowledge of a particular topographical region through cadaveric dissection.
• The confidence to work independently on a dissection, to effectively and efficiently achieve their own individual dissection aims.
• A professional set of practical anatomical skills acquired through systematic cadaveric examination and appraisal.
• An understanding of employment opportunities and applications of human anatomy in fields ranging from clinical medicine, education, biomechanics and human movement, and medical imaging, through examination of the literature and a topic of their choice.
• An ability to confidently communicate anatomical concepts and findings in a variety of formats to a broad audience.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is a core component in Year 3 of the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology. It is a practical module that includes cadaveric dissection in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC).

Over the course of a full semester, students conduct a thorough and systematic exploration of the gross and functional anatomy of a region of their choice, through cadaveric dissection and investigation into a unique research topic.

Students build upon the foundational knowledge and skills developed in earlier modules at an advanced level, gaining an appreciation of anatomical or clinical problems facing the modern world, and how their skills and knowledge can be applied towards solving these problems in various workplace settings.

The module will be assessed through a mixture of written, oral and practical tasks.
Outline Syllabus
This module concludes a series of practical human anatomy modules in the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology.

The module begins with selecting a region of the body according to the students’ interests, and proceeds with students working to produce a detailed anatomical prosection of that region. Students will be guided in this process by skilled academics who will provide guidance throughout the module.

Deeper knowledge is gained through an investigation into a research topic on the region they have chosen, by critically evaluating and communicating relevant scientific literature and concepts. Students will have a choice of contemporary issues in anatomy to focus on, which may include but are not limited to; functional anatomy and biomechanics, human movement, frailty and ageing, ailments, injuries and conditions that affect human health.

The module will conclude with a conference style event where students are assessed on their abilities to communicate science effectively in the form of a flash talk and poster.
Teaching and Learning Methods
HARC Practicals (36 hours): Takes place in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC). Interactive exploration of key anatomical structures through a regional approach. Includes individual cadaveric examination and dissection. Cadaveric dissection is an extremely active process. It requires real-time synthesis and comprehension of the structures encountered to successfully progress. During these guided practicals, students will have 1-2-1 feedback from the lead academic and anatomy demonstrators, who will ask questions and prompt discussion about the anatomy the students encounter and the research topic they choose.

Authentic assessment: An oral examination (viva) is a highly authentic assessment of specialist knowledge – in this case, a demonstration of their cadaveric prosection to summarise their anatomical knowledge. The communication assessment requires students to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge in a digestible manner in two different formats: a poster and a 3-minute flash talk. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Independent learning (114 hours): The student directed learning element of the module will involve: planning for their dissection procedure; directed anatomical reading and accessing online resources such as anatomical models; searching the literature and critically appraising articles. Drop-in sessions will also be available for independent dissection time. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Attendance Recorded: yes

The literature review and flash talk assessments help studens to develop an understanding of employment and the vast range of medical/clinical, laboratory, evolutionary, biomechanics and research topics that involve anatomy. Further to this, the students decide what area they want to focus on, so this is flexible if students are interested in clinical medicine, dentistry, physiotherapy, research or education.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed through a mixture of written, oral and practical tasks, including formative assessments for feedback and preparation for summative assessment. The assessments are highly authentic and develop important graduate attributes.

• Prosection quality and written reflection (500 words) on procedure and outcomes (Weighting 35% - TBC). This assesses the students planning, preparation and skills in dissection. To produce a detailed, clean and unique anatomical prosection, student will need to plan and revise the anatomy, problem solve and critically think about anatomical variation, and reflect on the procedure and outcomes. The accompanying written reflection will include their individual reflection on the dissection procedure/process, identification of anatomical variations, whether they achieved their original aims, and their personal self-reflection on progress, planning, and time management, to achieve the final prosection. The reflection should be personal and flexible.

• A science communication piece on a literature-based research topic related to the students prosection (Weighting 35% - TBC). This task requires students to choose an aspect of anatomy related to their prosection and explain its importance in an applied context of their choosing from independent research. They must produce two outputs, to communicate the same information in different formats: a poster and a 3-minute flash talk.

• Oral viva (Weighting 30% - TBC). A traditional face-to-face oral examination where students can demonstrate their anatomical knowledge of the prosection through a practical demonstration, followed by question and answers.

These assessment take various forms to ensure an inclusive mix of assignments and opportunities for students to learn. Formative opportunities to communicate their understanding of anatomy and their research topic will take place throughout the semester during 1-2-1 feedback with the lead academic and anatomy demonstrators during the guided practicals.

These assessments are authentic assessments (written, oral and practical tasks) that fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning, including how to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge in different formats.

Inclusion (EDI) has been considered in the design of these assessments for different learning styles and abilities by having a range of formats that favour different skills (a mixture of written, oral and practical tasks). Adjustments including late submissions and resits are in line with SOLS policies.

Reassessment for science communication piece and viva assessments the will use the same format but the topic my differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Due to the nature of the Prosection Assessment (continuous practical work on a dissection over 12 weeks), this assessment is not available as a resit. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submissions of written work.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Health and Safety
Practical sessions take place in Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC), where all activity must comply with Human Tissue Authority (HTA) regulations. Learners must not be aged under 18.
